number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Mars: War Logs is a cyberpunk rpg in which you fight the a corporation (or is a government?) called Abundance because they are the people that attack you.  Also you fight thugs and mole-things.Gameplay - It's pretty lacking.  The only time you interact with the world is when you dig through the trash or talk to a merchant.  There are also side quests to do, but they're not interesting and don't really have any affect on the environment.  It's like played bioware games, thought they ROCKED, and then didn't realize what they liked about them.  The combat's also pretty underwhelming.  It's a brawler (in the vein of Sleeping Dogs, just without the combos or useful interface) which would be fine, except for this terrible ability every enemy has; the ability to not take damage. Every so often, usually when you're doing well, they'll choose to jump back and avoid all of your damage.  This is a pretty big deal since there's no way to counter it (even if they're already against a wall) and you're usually against a large group of competant enemies.  Choosing to attack an enemy is a risky decision since they can all suddenly start tearing through you at any moment.  It's not even an issue of difficulty, it's an issue of poor design.  You're forced to spend most of each encounter rolling around waiting for your technopowers to rechargeStory - I feel like there could have been a really cool story here.  From what I gathered, it's based on a cool idea of corporate warfare on an unforgiving planet and the effects that can have on a population.  The problem is that the game does NOTHING with any of this.  It's like they start the game right after the end of a really cool game.  No part of the story is really explained beyond "these are the bad guys because just trust me" moments.  I mean, the whole first act of the game seems to only happen because of the main character's impatience.   I actually had to stop playing at the end of the second act because I was given a choice to make and realized that I had NO idea what anyone was talking about or trying to accomplish.Acting - I feel like it's important to be forgiving here; how many indie studios could talented voice actors? It's entirely possible that it was just the developers.  To their credit, there are some characters that are voiced in a perfectly acceptable fashion.  They're even able to give emotion!  The problem is that most of those characters are pretty throwaway.  The MAIN cast, on the other hand, all sound ridiculous.  Either they're "bad♥♥♥♥♥female roles" that sound like 7 year olds or they're the protagonist who, oh my god, has not changed his tone once through the entire game.World Design - Like I said before, they really could have done a lot here. I mean, a dystopian, cyberpunk world set on MARS?  Instead they just made everything orange and dirty.  I actually had to rely on my map to get anywhere because the areas were so confusing and samey.  I also said this before, but nothing you do changes anything and there are only like ten characters that say anything in the whole game.RPG Elements - Pretty lack luster.  The progression trees mostly just boost damage or give uninteresting boosts like being able to react faster after being hit.  Then there's the feat system that gives four types of boosts; increased xp from enemies, increased loot from enemies, more crafting options (crafting's mostly just for upgrading your gear), and better stuff from recycling gear.  There are also some perks from the morality system but the only ones that are useful come from being a bad guy (the good guy perks involve slightly decreased prices from merchants which you NEVER use and increased damage/health for your companion, which is probably just going to stand there being hit anyway).Achievements - Nothing too hard, but it's worth mentioning that there's an achievement for doing all the side quests.  They're pretty finicky and will actually become unavailable if you do them in the wrong order.Final Thoughts - I love when indie devs take on something that's probably more than they can chew; it shows they're driven!  So, for the first four hours I managed to ignore a bunch of the flaws with the game.  It wasn't until the end of the first act when a character who had no reason to die was killed purely to create dramatic tension (and failed to do so, by the way) that it really clicked with me that there was something actually WRONG with the game.  I can't really recommend this game, but I'd suggest you keep an eye on this development team; this game was bad, but it seems like a step in the right direction.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												Hmm where to start.  Biggest sleeper hit of the year?  I think so.  Haven't been pleasantly surprised by a game from a dev I'd not played before.  This game has everything.  Awesome Sci-fi setting somewhere inbetween cyberpunk and post-apocolyptic.  It not pure polish, but its pure heart.  No crashes and nothing really broken in it.  The quests are enjoyable as is the main story.  Lots of side quests and like the main ones you have actual choices that not only affect the games outcome but also the NPCs in the game as well as your companions.  The later plays a good size role in the game and you can have one with you nearly the entire time who help you in combat (no control over their actions though).  And the combat--Awesome.  If Dragon Age 2 had used this combat system it would have been way better.  There's no combo system in combat but you have to use a combination of your melee attack, dodge, counter-attack, kick etc.  you get powers later in the game which are also key especially the shield.  the only ranged combat in the game besides your powers is a nail gun and grenades.  both of which are not used to often though as their supply is limited though they can be bought or crafted.  and crafting this is also something that this game is superb at. you collect lots of items which are used in crafting either supplys and or upgrades to your two equipment slots, your melee weapon and your armor.  both have a lot of customizable options and you can even recycle your stuff to get back some crafting supplies.  the skill tree is also highly customizable but not overly complicated.  and you wont be able to unlock even close to it all so that is nice unlike other games.  stealth build is an option though their were really only a couple instances that it seemed highly viable and worth the points in it.  this game has all the hallmarks of a great RPG while also being a enjoyable melding between an engaing sci-fi story/world and a highly rewarding combat experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												It was difficult to decide whether to recommend this game or not. As a summary, I would say this is a game for sci-fi fans that prioritize story over game play and are not afraid to sacrifise game-play and graphic looks to delve into a slightly unusual universe and an OK story.What was good in this game: a) The story was in addition to dialogue and cut scenes told through diary entries, which helped keep up with what is going on. b) Good character and location descriptions. c) Technomancy replaced magic here, which is an interesting skill to master and play with.What could have been better: a) The game's graphics are very outdated, there are not many details to look at both when it comes to pure graphical looks, and immersive details. b) Almost all side-quests involve doing something and returning for reward: there is simply too much running from A to B, back to A and B again. If the world was more immersive, it might be more fun this way, but now it can be a little bit boring. A good thing is it doesn't take too much time to run like that. c) Voice acting could have been better in certain places to make the story more immersive.Neutral points to note: a) The game is majorly linnear, with a few exceptions. b) Fighting is basic and not very complex, but made more fun through Technomancy skill tree. c) The world is limited to the player, there are invisible borders here and there, but mostly there is walking in corridors between structures and rock walls.I chose to recommend this game, mostly because of the story and the way it was presented through diary entries and descriptions. Although the story itself isn't very immersive or more than averagely engaging, it kept me interested enough to finish the game. However, I would like to note that the story and universe they built in this game had several parts which would have been very interesting to learn more about. Simply put, there are some pretty interesting ideas, but it is a pity the game never explores them (more deeply). So try this if you aren't bothered by above mentioned negative and neutral points.

La storia è fredda in una realtà dove solo quelli che non hanno scrupoli sopravvivono, e dove i più forti comandano i più deboli...somiglia alla controparte malvagia di un universo parallelo di Mass Effect. Insomma...godetevi il gioco :3 Spero di essere stata utile <3 Ci si vede!

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I've played through to completion in 3 days. I really enjoyed it.I'm one of those people that happily play old games, so maybe that's why the graphics didn't bother me like some people.Combat wasn't great, though, I'll admit. There were times that I could storm through a group of enemies with no issues, and others where they just seemed to destroy me. I don't really know why. Stealth isn't terribly useful, and blocking seemed slower than it should be. It should come as no surprise that Technomancy becomes very very useful.The story was good. It wasn't amazing, but I'd enjoy some sort of sequel or spin-off, if one ever came out. There were a few different options to the storyline, too. I will say that I was annoyed that I couldn't finish Devotion's quest, and I never did figure out why (I'd even turned the other one down completely), but honestly, the relationship quests weren't anything amazing anyway, and the idea of being with either on the General's side made me feel a little squiffy, since they both seem so brainwashed. The only other issue I had the occasional clipping of dead bodies and a missing achievement (Got Ch 2 and 3, no Ch 1, probably Steam's fault, really). Nothing even slightly game breaking.Overall, I thought it was really good, and I'd recommend it, if you like Mass Effect or any other sort of game like this. It's not as good, but I think the developer could really get somewhere with a little support.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												What a great game!  Not perfect mind you, but great!  Finally a company truly sees how great a game like Mass Effect can be, and the need for more games like that inspired by its mechanics.  Mars War Logs is that game!  A great sci-fi adventure where your decisions shape the story and truly matter!!!  I hope more companies see this, and make more games like this.  Here are the pros:Pros:- Branching decisions that make you truly feel like a hero who shapes his destiny- Great story with interesting characters- Stunning and Gorgeous graphics- A short but satisfying inclusion of a love interest- Combat that's really fun and reminiscent of the Batman Arkham games (Asylum, City, and Origins)!Like I said before, the game's not perfect.  There are some serious cons that can't be overlooked.  Despite an annoying camera that you have to fight with during every fight scene, the biggest cons come from artificially padding the game's length.  In fact, I think this game could've been cut down to a respectable 8 to 10 hours runtime if the developers took care in tightening up the experience.  Here are the cons: Cons:- The game's built around fetch quests.  In fact, that along with repetitive battles make up 90% of the experience.  These fetch quests are so overly abundant that you're constantly going from point A, to point B, then back to point A, then back again to point B, and yet again back to point A, and so on...  You get the picture.  The first chapter alone made me quit for awhile, because I thought this was it.  I'm glad I stuck it through.- Overuse of respawning fights.  Holy crap!  You finish the first chapter, which is a myriad of fetch quests, and then the second chapter greets you with a never ending barrage of respawning enemies.  You win a fight getting to your first fetch quest objective, then you're told to go back to the area where the fetch quest began, and on your way back, all the guys you've just killed have come back to life in the same positions they were in when you first fought them.  Like I said before, I love the game's battle system, but when you have to tread a same area 20+ times, and fight the same enemies each time, it gets tiresome.  The use of this tired JRPG trope has never been fun.    Conclusion:Even with its glaring cons, Mars War Logs is worth playing all the way to the end.  It even succeeds where Mass Effect failed at the end of its trilogy; a satisfying ending based upon all the choices you've made.  Developer Spiders knows how to treat its customers with respect by offering a complete RPG package without holding parts of the game (story DLC) behind pay walls like Electronic Arts/Bioware (you still can't buy the complete Mass Effect Trilogy with all its story content in a complete collection).  I hope more companies like Spiders take the approach of offering the complete story/side stories in game, and avoid big corporation BS of nickel and diming their customers, and never letting them own their copy of the content.  [Note:  Not speaking bad about DLC, actually I like some forms of DLC, just not the way some companies handle, distribute, or manage it; see said example above.]Sadly, I can't recommend Mars War Logs at full price, because of its cumbersome experience, but it is a game everyone who likes these types of games should play.  There have been several 75% off sales and the game is well worth it at that price.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Mars: War Logs is an odd chimera. The graphics aren't bad for an indie game, and the concepts behind it are fairly solid and intriguing. Unfortunately, there are a lot of technical details that mar the experience, but overall it's a game worth buying - if you're getting it cheap.Combat can (and likely will) be frustrating until you learn all the right tricks. You'll always be outnumbered, often four or five to one, and most foes need to be hit a dozen times before they'll fall - while just five or six hits will often kill you. Expect to spend a lot of time manically rolling from side to side as you try to evade them, or invest heavily in explosives to end combat as quickly as possible.The voice acting is passable, but crude. A number of the voice actors adopt 'silly' voices as they leapfrog from character to character, and several of the actors actually say something entirely different from what the subtitles are saying. Although the main character's voice is decent enough, I found myself often skipping through awkwardly delivered (and profanity-riddled) lines with greater regularity as the game progressed.There are moral choices present in the game, but they're generally very basic. Do you want to murder these people for a few extra dollar? Well then that's evil, and it will be reflected in your reputation. Do you NOT want to murder these people? Oh, well then you're a decent guy. Congrats. It rarely gets much more in-depth then that, though.On the plus side, though, both the skills and the crafting system are fairly well done. Every skill you unlock gives you a very tangible benefit or ability, making it difficult to choose which one you want. Crafting is almost required to progress, and acts as an invaluable aid, both for crafting 'one-use' items like grenades or health injectors and for modifying your basic weapons and armor.All in all, I'd give Mars: War Logs a 7 out of 10. Worth the buy, if you're getting it for ten dollars or less.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Clearly a low budget game, but I thoroughly enjoyed it nonetheless. The story was very interesting and kept me playing through somewhat tedious quests. The voice acting could have been better in some places and often didn't match the on-screen text, but it didn't detract from the playability or enjoyment, in my opinion. I liked the variety of melee weaponry and wardrobe, as well as the crafting aspects and skill trees. I would have liked at least one more type of gun, however, since there was only one (that I could find). Also love that it offered full controller support, always a big plus for me. I think a DLC or two could add a lot to this game and I would buy in a heartbeat. Overall, I really enjoyed Mars: War Logs and I hope to see more polished games from this dev.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Despite many negative reviews from critics, and despite some flaws, for the most part I enjoyed this game and thought it was solid. The story takes place in a gritty, dystopian, almost post-apoc setting and spans 3 chapters. There are a lot of sidequests and character interactions, and the game tends to alternate between big open areas and linear levels, which in my opinion provided a nice change pace.Perhaps what I liked the most was the levelling and the combat. The fighting was incredibly fun, a little awkward at first, but easy to get used to. And the customization of your weapon and armour is great. You get to find various tools and crafting parts that you can use on your gear to give it additional bonuses of your choice. The levelling had 3 different mastery trees - combat, renegade (support abilities like healing and stealth), and technomancy (electrical powers). The levelling happened very frequently, which was great too, since you didn't have to wait for ages to get to the skills you've had your eyes on.The story and setting are pretty interesting. I personally found chapters 1 and 2 to be brilliant, but chapter 3 fell flat on its face. It almost felt as though the game was rushed at the end. What was most interesting perhaps is how at the end of chapter 2 you get a choice of split paths to join one of the 2 factions, which changes some things in chapter 3, but ultimately you end up visiting the exact same locations regardless of which faction you go with. The premise of split paths for the final chapter is fantastic, but the execution resulted in a diluted experience. Going with the Resistance at least was a half-decent attempt at a conclusion that presented some more moral choices down the line. But going with the general felt like it was added into the game at the very last minute just for the sake of having this split path feature.The game also had 3 romance options in it, but this too felt rather lacking and devoid of much dialogue. A few other NPCs felt like they should've gotten more screen time than they actually did, like the bounty hunter friend of the main character. But apart from that, most characters were rather interesting.Overall I'd recommend this game. It's a decent sci-fi cyberpunk RPG and I was immersed for the duration of playing it, even going as far as trying out both story paths for its somewhat disappointing conclusion.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Everything about this game is a good effort, but nothing more than 6/10. The combat is OK, but you don't really get to use all of the skills effectively because the "magic" type skills take so long to cast that enemies have time to hit you and interrupt the casting and you can only use them to buff if you get a chance before the fight starts.The last battle is very underwhelming and you expect there's going to be a grand finale, but there isn't.Equipment and crafting is OK, but the weapons are all variations on clubs with different stats. None of them perform differently or have any character.The universe they have created is OK, level design is very linear, and the story is again, just OK; neither the main plot line or the characters really draw you in. Mars:War Logs isn't atrocious, but you could be spending your time on a game that's more fun...

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												I cant really say that there was to much that stood out to me in Mars War Logs. I had hoped this game would fill a small chunk of time with a decent RPG, and I wasn't expecting much really. However, I was expecting something better than this. The game itself doesn't look all too pretty, even on highest settings. The voice acting is really, really bad, and the characters themselves are really hard to take seriously (Of course the kid named Innocence has to almost get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by a guy named Fatty...). When you have a character that is so driven to kill you that she abandoned her order, almost get herself killed, then gets saved by you and realizing you're not the monster she thought (with little to no insistence from yourself) you may think that yes, she may decide to join with you. What I don't expect is for her to wake up, spend 30 seconds in your presence (that's not an exaggeration), then offer to paint the taint with you since you are her new mentor. It wholeheartedly broke any respect for future character development I had for this game. Moving on, the back story is very poorly conveyed, the description states that water is scarce and wars are being fought over it, but I never heard mention of water once. The crafting system seems minimal, and the levels themselves feel like they are empty, even though NPC's meander about before you. I will say the combat system does feel similar to the Witcher, but isn't nearly as fluid or responsive. All in all I wasn't impressed. It's not a terrible, mind numbing experience, but it didn't hold my attention long enough to finish it. And to be honest that rarely happens.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Mars: War Logs is a game I really wanted to like.But it just fails to come together as a cohesive whole.And that's the tragic part, this game has so many parts that should be amazing but every step of the way there are little hiccups that bring it down.The game, for me, felt drawn out by bad loading screens as I climbed up or down from items, cringed at horrible dialog, wondered as recruitable NPCs went from bloody vengance to being my friend after a single line of dialog, was gobsmacked as the game forgot to tell me crucial plot important details, and the combat never gained the depth one would have liked.I wanted to like this game, I wanted it to succeed, but it didn't.I hold the greatest hope that these people will try again and their next product will be a polished RPG worthy of great praise from all the lessons learned from this one.But I'm afraid I can't recommend it to anybody.

												Having a blast with this game. Kind of a mix between Mass Effect (character dialog choices and reputation system), Fallout (loot, overall setting and crafting) and Skyrim (real time combat + dodges and parries). The level design leaves a lot to be desired and even the updated V/O dialog is still not great. But the atmosphere, the story, the characters, the combat, the crafting are all very interesting and fun. Also it's not the longest game, but at 1/3rd the price of most new games, I can't really complain. Hope to see a bigger sequel from the same developers.

Posted: July 13, 2013
												Having a blast with this game. Kind of a mix between Mass Effect (character dialog choices and reputation system), Fallout (loot, overall setting and crafting) and Skyrim (real time combat + dodges and parries). The level design leaves a lot to be desired and even the updated V/O dialog is still not great. But the atmosphere, the story, the characters, the combat, the crafting are all very interesting and fun. Also it's not the longest game, but at 1/3rd the price of most new games, I can't really complain. Hope to see a bigger sequel from the same developers.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												At first I really liked this game... but after awhile I couldn't stand the combat system. I basically got out of the first area and then restarted, and tried a new character build. But it's actually the combat system that I can't stand, so I can't play it.It uses a similar combat system to the Witcher 2 (attack, block, evade). The problem is that the AI of your companions is useless, if you have any companions, and that if you are fighting two opponents you're guaranteed to lose at rock paper scissors, since one of the two will be countering you, and the other will kill you. That means you're constantly trying to evade and get occasional hits in, in really cramped quarters. It's just not fun combat, at all.

												I was excited about this game at first, but after playing it for a few hours i have grown very frustrated with this game.First the story was hard to get into, and I didn't feel as if I was being engaged, I didn't feel a reason to care about anything that was happening in the world.Second battle mechanics were very anoying, being ganged up on by six enemies at once was tedious and a task, being unable to aim with the nail gun was aslo annoying and would have been a good addition to the game play. blocking always seemed to be impossible for me and it seemed as if every other move for the A.I. was a knockbak hit.Third the upgrade and loot system are broken, and i felt that i wasn't given enough options, and i felt that i wasn't rewarded for defeating six enemies.The game looked nice though, i would have prefered more diversity, but otherwise the creatures looked cool and were creatively made.All in all i would say pass on this game .

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												3/10This game should be called 'Mars: Evasive Rolls and Gophering'  because that is virtually all you will be doing. Things you can do in Mars: War Logs, listed by frequency:Sick Rolls: You will die almost immediately without them. 90% of your battle strategy will be somersaults, side rolls, and back rolls).Getting things for apparent invalids: Everyone needs something, and, yes, it is on the other side of the bland and lifeless map.Listen to mind-numbing dialog and fifth-rate voice acting: The mish mash of accents and hammed-up acting is intense.Sell all your items one by one: You know how most games allow you to sell items two, or even three, at a time? Not Mars: War Logs. You must sell everything one by one, even if you have fifty of them. Enjoy!Crafting objects that are way more expensive then just buying them: To craft a health injection costs 20 serum, to buy one costs 8. Do the math.Putting sick plates on your dusty clothes: Now you can look like an awesome post-apocalyptic warrior, or maybe you can look like Kevin Costner in The Postman.Actually fighting: When you aren't busy gophering, crafting, and getting lulled into a rage-coma by the silly acting and storytelling, you can beat enemies with improvised weapons. Yes, we are far into the future, but due to apparent reason guns, laser swords, and fun weapons don't exist in this sparse world. You get to beat up on your enemy with light fixtures and mole creature bones.Pros of Mars: War Logs: You will be momentarily distracted from all the evil in this world by this catastrophe. You will get to practice your digital gymnastic skills (except for jumping, because why jump over things when you can roll right past them?).Cons: Playing Mars: War Logs is a lot like playing Solitare. It's basically a way to tell your friends and family that you are exceptionally bored and have nothing on your plate at the moment. It's inviting people to give you a menial task to do, much like the NPCs in Mars: War Logs. Don't let it happen.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Absolutely dreadful game. Terrible camera that can be quite nauseating in smaller areas, as you try to navigate your way around, but even worse in combat situations when you cant see what you need to target.The controls are beyond stupid, who ever decided on the layout should be taken outside and,,,,given a very stern talking to, Right Stick turns the camera, if you press it, it locks onto an enemy, so in a confined space, as you try to get the camera into a decent position whilst in combat, you will wind up inadvertently changing target lock onto an enemy you cannot see. The Left Stick controls movement, it also makes you go into a stealth crouch, in combat, when you are trying to dodge around enemies, you sometimes wind up motionless in a stealth crouch, while the enemies beat up on you and you cannot respond.Alot of combat revolves around dodging behind enemies to hit their weak spot, but oftentimes the dodge is slow to react or you dodge in the completely opposite way to the direction in which you intended to dodge.The camera, while being quite jerky also seems quite close to your characters back, so it inhibits you from having a decent view of your surroundings, so when you are trying to follow the really childish and useless map, you spend alot of time trying to find a decent view of the area to see where you need to go.Graphics are servicable, but they can be quite bland, which at times makes differentiating where you can and cannot go a bit of a chore.Story is pretty decent, but the voice acting robs it of any intensity, the characters dont seem to care, which kind of rubs on to you after awhile, so you dont really care either. The characters names are quite bizarrre, but the main bad guy being called Sean doesnt tend to instill any sense of dread, but I guess it's not as bad as the names of the rest of the characters.I had to stop playing, I got sick of fighting the camera and the controls, the story gave me no motivation to ignore these factors, I got the game really cheap, (maybe 3-4 quid) and I still feel cheated.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												This is a rough one to thumbs up or down, I wish there was a neutral option (pay attention Steam!).  The game is pretty decent, and once you figure out the combat problems and techniques (yes, problems), it's a decent play.  However, the ovewhelmingly big issue is technomancy.  Everyone in the game world talks about technomancers like they are gods.  You turn out to be one and can use these powers.  Except you will NEVER be able to use these powers.  They are amazingly slow, so there is no way you can ever use them in a fight, other than if there is a single opponent who is focused on your companion, and at that point you may as well just club them instead.  They missed a huge opportunity with this massive design flaw to allow you to play different styles of character.  This continues through the other combat options as well, they simply are not designe well enough to allow for anything other than one style of play, when there could be 3 easily.  So, if you ignore technomacny entirely, never waste skill points on it, never try to use it, just focus on grenades, sneaking, and melee as your main points of combat (the occaisional trap and nail gun attack are fine too), then it's a decent play.  Unfortunately the other major flaw is that side quests never show objective markers like main quests, so that's pretty frustrating as well.  Get it on 60% off or more sale, it's not worth paying full price, and there are probably more enjoyable games to blow time on.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Spoiler tags used where necessary.Quick Review:Mars: War Logs may have had a very rough start, but the patches and English dialogue overhaul make it a great experience for anyone who enjoys meaningful quests, a believable world, and realistic characters. I clocked in 30 hours before being completely finished with my first playthrough. My only recommendation for anyone considering purchasing it is to watch a gameplay video showing the combat, because it's likely to turn certain people away immediately. Try to play it like a hack & slash and you will die endlessly.Currently, it has its share of tiny errors that can be easily missed if players aren't looking for them.To avoid bugs/glitches, update your computer's graphics controller, audio controller, and verify the integrity of game cache before playing.Computer: Compaq Presario CQ57-439WM Notebook PCOperating System: Windows 7 Home Premium 64bitGamepad: Logitech Dual Action w/Logitech ProfilerIn-Depth Review://Level DesignThe level design is so well thought out that the entire world feels expansive and every location feels like what it is. Mole caves feel like enclosed spaces with only one exit. Shadowlair feels like a city full of life and people going about their lives even if they aren't happy to be alive. The structures above Roy and the paths he isn't allowed to take, even though they are right in front of him, all make the world feel existent.An hour into the game, the level design reminded me of Phantom Dust. Fourteen hours later, it still did. This isn't a negative trait in the slightest.//CombatCombat is challenging, but simple. Attack, guard-break, block, counter, and dodge make up the basic maneuvers. What players spend their skill points on after leveling-up make up the fun part.Excluding boss fights, players can flee to the next area of a level to skip combat altogether. This could lead to a need for grinding as the game progresses, unfortunately.The response time prevents button mashing since doing so will prevent players from making the quick decisions that are a constant part of combat. There's basically a half-second delay for every movement Roy makes.Party members can hold their own, but not for very long. Their main purpose is to distract enemies while the Roy eliminates as many as he can before they inevitably fall unconscious. They cannot be healed by the player, but their health is fully restored at the end of every battle. This system forces players to engage in combat rather than hide and adds an invisible timer set to how long they have until every conscious enemy gangs up on them. Yep. >TechnomancyThe Technomancer skill tree is a worthy investment due to how fun and powerful it is. Too many enemies? Electric Arc. A single enemy with a high armor rating? Charged Weapon. Feeling overwhelmed? Energy Shield. The more you experiment, the more fun you'll have.>StealthStealth is worth investing in for players who prefer not to go on all-out frontal assaults and enjoy thinning out the enemy first. There are some very tricky levels where playing as a stealth-based character becomes a challenge, but figuring out who to eliminate first and when to do so is part of the fun. Enemies are alerted by fallen comrades and will alert others if players don't quiet them quickly enough. Only further down the Renegade skill tree can players invest in hiding fallen enemies from sight.Party members stay in place and out the way until Roy exits from stealth mode. Since a patrolling enemy can still spot them, players can push party members wherever they want by running into them.//Boss FightsTo my recollection, there are six challenging boss fights in the game. None felt misplaced or thrown in.My only complaint is that, at the final level of the game, there should have been an actual boss fight before the endscene. One or two powerful technomancers that Roy and/or Mary knew from their past would have done the trick.//QuestsThere are more than enough non-mandatory side quests that get players more engulfed in the game world. Not a single quest is dull and pointless. All bring the world together and add character to its many inhabitants.Quest can go anywhere from helping ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and mutants to stopping serial killers and spying on a political figure. Get ready for some odd situations you may not have been prepared for.//Party MembersThe party members are interesting characters with their own motives, back-stories, and personalities. Personal favorite: Mary. She will say the darnest, hilarious, and most sad things.Players get a choice between three female love interests and gain five party members total. Only four of these five are available for each playthrough, however, and only one is allowed to accompany Roy at a time.Party members actually comment on Roy's decisions (serum extraction and dialogue) every now and then. Those moments help breath life into his character and theirs.//DialogueConversations are well written and funny. There are even references here and there.Players get different options of what to say to NPC's. Some choices will cause Roy to engage in combat and others will cause him to evade it.Get ready for some hilarious conversations.Thanks to the dialogue, I've found myself caring about the characters I met throughout the game. This really backfired when people died.//EndingI enjoyed the Aurora ending cutscenes I got, especially the last one.The endlevel, on the other hand, was lacking in impact. I may have gotten the impression that this was it, but the lack of dialogue during the entire level made it similar to a non-boring grind without the need to level up.I'll give Spiders this much, they were successful in making a grinding level that was entertaining and barely felt like a grind. Unfortunately, they did not give it thrill, impact, or emotion.The dialogue between Roy and his follower at the end was great, though. Just one more moment like or leading up to that beforehand would have done the trick for me.Even having Honour	 speaking out loud about the 'endboss', and adding backstory in the process, would have tremendously helped players care about what happened next. It would have also helped us understand the choice that was made in the first endscene.It's a matter of character depth. More was given in the endscene for Honour and the 'endboss', but not quite enough. For me, the 'endboss' was the only character who lacked depth. All we really got were the reasons for said character's actions, which make sense and explain his/her villainy.Other than the lack of impact and a boss, the endlevel was perfectly fine.//OthersPlayers must choose one of two factions (Resistance or Aurora) two-thirds of the way through the game. Both come with their own female party member / love interest.There are multiple opportunities to end some NPC's lives outside of extracting Serum from defeated foes. This includes resolving conflicts for quests and actually killing one of the potential party members either directly or by abandonment.Serum extracting isn't necessary unless players want to do a 'Dark Side' playthrough, which affects the merchants' prices, intimidation skills of the player, and reactions of party members.The actual war logs used in the game is a nice touch. It adds first person perspective immersion for those who are interested. Think of the journal from the Elder Scrolls series or, more accurately, Arcanum: Of Steamworks & Magick Obscura.There's even a bestiary that includes NPCs and locations.The main menu and combat menu are both very well designed. It took me some time to remember which menu tab (equipment, stats, etc) had what, though.Weapon, armor, item, and component crafting adds an extra layer of strategy to the game. There are no wrong combinations. It all comes down to what works best for your play style.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												This game is a great example of what happens when a developer sets his ambition way too high, and creates something that he is not capable of creating. He might have had great ideas, but because his skill was not that great, he ended up creating something of mediocre worth rather than a grand masterpiece. And what a shame it is, because this game did indeed have some potential. Gameplay wise, it is essentially Witcher 2 combined with Mass Effect, but without any of the things that made both games great. Much of the choices that you make don't really matter, and the morality system is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, as all the bonuses that it gives you don't really help at all, nor does the morality system majorly change the way people look at you. The bonus that you get for being a man with an excellent reputation doesn't help due to how useless your NPC party members are, thanks to the fact that the AI in the game for party members sucks♥♥♥♥♥and due to how quickly they die. Merchants are pretty useless unless you are trying to complete certain plot related quests that involve giving serum (money) to NPCs by selling off♥♥♥♥♥♥you don't need or are in need of serum for making meds to use in combat. You can pretty much get a lot of the items you need by looting enemies or by finding some junk piles or crates that are put across the map. Speaking of serum, it is admittedly an interesting kind of currency, but as mentioned before, it's only really useful for those two things, and just like most items, you loot it from crates and enemies. The way you loot it from enemies though is usually through a serum extractor, which apparently kills some guy who should already be dead after being beaten mercilessly by a pipe with a cleaver, and using the serum extractor on a guy who should have already been dead by now also lowers your reputation. Like that totally makes any sense. Had it not been for the skill level cap of three instead of two, it would have been safe to say that the game's skill tree system is an exact rip off of Witcher 2's skill tree. Now, character building is one of the better things about this game, but sadly there still are a couple of problems. For instance, the renegade skill tree has skills that suppossedly help improve the stealth in this game, but stealth is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing useless thanks to how poorly it's implemented. I know Witcher 2 has some questionable stealth as well, but at least that game didn't have you go out of stealth mode after attempting to knock out an enemy or had skills in the skill tree related to a mechanic that was pretty much pointless. The perk system is also pretty stupid. Do X amount of things several times and you can then wait till you level up a few times in order to get X amount of Character Perk Points just to purchase X perk. Why not give the perk after doing X thing several times, or do what the Fallout series does, and give out a perk every few levels. Some perks are also tied to your morality level, which is something that I find to be really stupid. Not being able to use charismatic and intimidative dialogue choices unless your character is (or was at one point) with a good or bad rep shows that the game's view on morality is worse than that of an elementary schooler. Of course, as mentioned before, most of your choices do jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ so what's the point anyways? Combat is pretty much ripped straight from Witcher 2. Everything from the ability to slow down time and switch your skills to the roll n' doge - stab - block gameplay of Witcher 2, with the exception that you can actually heal during combat. It's too bad that the camera can cause you to ♥♥♥♥ up, and although not at the teir of Kingdom Hearts Camera Bad, it still is pretty shoddy. There are also bombs, traps and ranged weapons just like the ones from Witcher 2, but the variety is quite lacking. In fact, you only get one type of trap, one type of gun (a nail gun, which makes me question how they could only have those and not♥♥♥♥♥♥like machine guns and laser pistols), and one type or bomb. The game also allows you one AI-controlled party member (this is where the Mass Effect elements come in), though you might as well be playing without the AI, because about 95% of the time, I found the AI for party members to be one of the most incompetent things ever, as it dies faster than a still-born baby in the womb, and that's even when you tell it to focus on defense. Not being able to go through your party member's equipment in order to give them better weapons and armor doesn't make it any better. The game is also full of stupid invisible walls, and the enviorments are a bore to explore, as you can only enter places that the game deems important. You cannot even enter a single house that belongs to some random person. The civillian NPCs in the game must be the most ballin' people in the universe, because they don't get scared if you pull out your weapon in front of them! Side quests ♥♥♥♥ing suck, as they are primarilly the same boring fetch quests found in plenty of other RPGs, and their rewards usually aren't worth it. Finally, there's crafting, and cliche as it sounds, crafting is perhaps the game's best feature, though I do find it stupid that you can access the craft screen during battle.Before I talk about the story, I would like to say that I wouldn't call the setting a cyberpunk one, as it looks more like an apocalyptic low-tech wasteland with some minor cyberpunk and space opera elements rather than a cyberpunk world full of men with cyberarms that act as weapons mowing down corparates from the local mega-corp. Having hi-tech gloves that let you shoot beams of electricity doesn't make it a cyberpunk game either. The game does however have an interesting setting, despite how generic of a setting Mars tends to be. Of course, the game has to have poorly explained lore that is extremely hard to follow, and this is despite the patch that was suppossed to fix a lot of the problems with the script. The characters? I didn't really like any of them, and the way the characters act is so unreal that I highly doubt that anyone could truly care for them. My least favorite charcters would have to either be Roy or Mary. Roy because he's the typical man with a mysterious past type of character, and Mary because she suddenly goes from being this ♥♥♥♥♥ who wants to kill you and hates your guts to this ♥♥♥♥♥ who wants to ♥♥♥♥ you just because you saved her, and she doesn't even have a hint of suspicion about you afterwards. Presentation wise, the game is what you would expect from a small studio. Not too bad, but there could have been way more colours than just orange, red, black and grey. Character designs range from okay to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ looking, Mary included. Enviorments tend to be boring as hell, and as mentioned before, are not very explorable due to how many invisible walls there are. The music is pretty forgettable as well. Finally, there's the voice acting, and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is it bad most of the time. Sometimes, it's actually quite funny, while other times it's cringe worthy, and of course there's always the mixture of the two. Now, I should note that it is better than the voice acting that was in the game at launch, but it still is a long way from being good. In conclusion, Mars War Logs is average at its best, and mediocre at its worst, and, at least in my opinion, is not worth its current price tag, nor is it an RPG that I would recommend to people looking for a great RPG experience. If, however, you still want to give the game a go, do what I did, and buy it on sale for really cheap. If I had to give it a rating, the most I would give it would be a 5/10.

content:

												I rarely stop playing a game after such a short time, but honestly this is really bad. number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Probably one of the most frustrating yet uninteresting combat systems I've encountered.  Granted, I'm only a couple hours into the game but it's already lost me.  Your companions are next to useless, walking pylons at best, and you spend the majority of most battles leaping around the battlefield or blocking a flurry of blows in order not to get stunlocked.  I don't mind a challenge, Darksouls/Demonsouls are difficult games but there you at least feel like you lost a fair fight.  This game is just tedious.I'm going to refrain from commenting on the story, haven't experienced enough to give it a fair shake.  However, so far the majority of the quests have been fairly bland in nature (talk to person A or find enough of part B) which are usually solved by walking around talking/clicking on everything until it says you did what you're supposed to.  A few of the quests appear to have some branching paths, which I regard as a good effort, but ultimately aren't really used that effectively and end up being fairly bland.I might go back and give it another shot at some point, but at the moment I'm glad I only spend $5 on this.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												It's not that this game is bad, per say. It's just...okay. I picked this up really cheap and beat it. It's not something I really regret, just nothing I can recommend to anyone looking for a good RPG. It's got issues with game balance (you always feel underpowered and the only abilities really worth using are the nailgun, grenades and energy shield.), the final area can bug out near the end if you use stealth and companions are only useful as a distraction.To be fair, the voice work isn't too bad, the story is actually not that bad, everything looks decent and I like the weapon and armour customisation. It seems like this could have been a lot better than it ended up being. I chalk it up to inexperience on the developer's part. If it's on sale again, you could certainly do worse but don't buy full price.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag.The combat is decent enough, you can acquire a pretty large variety of skills to make unique playstyles.  The enemy's attacks have unusual hitoxes and will whiff if you're too close.  When an enemy takes too much damage at one time, they'll have a kind of "dodge timer" where they will dodge out of the majority of player attacks for set amount of time.  This feels like a lazy way to prevent infinite hitstun from player attacks and can sometimes punish the player for no real reason.Difficulty scaling is poorly done, enemy's health and damage increases dramatically and possibly activates dodge time more quickly.  Beginning game becomes rather brutal.Plot takes quite a while to actually develop.  More like 2 plotlines that are loosely connected.The hub worlds are alright, although they start to feel more like a chore as the game goes on.The equipment and skill management is where this game shines.  Each skill feels like it adds something major to your gameplan without making it feel like you simply "outlevel" encounters.  The equipment modification system is really nice and helps completement your skill build.  But, unfortunately your options are very limited until roughly halfway through the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												It really pains me to give this game a thumbs down. We all want to see indie developers with nothing but guts and ambition show the big studios what-for. In this case however, it was just too ambitious for a small team. There's nothing outright offensive about the title, (other than the voice acting... Good God...) but neither is there anything noteworthy. The combat is a bad version of The Witcher 2 with only a few enemy types, the story is a bad version of Red Faction with little nuance and the dialog is... Awful in every way. There's no reason to play this game over the games that inspired it. Then you factor in a forgettable soundtrack, muddy graphics, awkward animations, and limited itemization and I can't really recommend Mars: War Logs to anyone. The highest praise I can give is that the crafting system is unique and highly customizable, but the itemization and combat are so bad that you'd rather just end the game quicker. Here's hoping that Spiders's next game is a hit!

You have mines, grenades, nail guns etc to try to break up the group attacks but it rarely works and you will be over powered again and again by unfair groups of enemies. number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Mars: War Logs is an indie rpg developed by Spiders who recently brought us Bound by Flame. Both games look exciting first, but suffer from certain problems which break the gameplay.Pros:There are still a few parts of the game, that may persuade the player to give a chance to the product. The graphics are okay, there is not much to see, but overall the places and people are believable, however do not expect anything fancy. The game kicks off better as it progresses later. I liked the soundtrack in the main menu, which gives the mood. In the early fights also the combat feels good, I had the feeling that something good will come. There are customization options also, which are somewhat in-depth. You can reinforce your gear, both weapons and armor for example with different materials. There are also options to make things out of junk, like medpacks, ammo, etc. The story and dialogues are consumable, nothing really poetic or anything, but it is still one of the better parts of the overall experience. You also have some optional choices which will influence your reputation.Cons:And, here comes the cons, because the game has a lot of them. As I got involved into bigger and harder fights I started to see clearly how the combat system cannot handle them. When you face more than 3 enemies at the same time it is starting to get difficult to plan your moves. The target system is not working as intended, and without it you can hardly keep track the movement of the enemy. Usually I get about half a minute before Innocence is incapacitated and all the enemies rush at me. The best tactic is to flee, but there is simply not enough room to do so. The skills also need time to activate, and as the opposite fighters are moving fast, it is almost impossible to use them due to interruption. Overall combat is a mess, nothing more. Also the are problems with the corpses. After some fights I needed to search after the bodies, because they stuck into the wall, and cannot be seen right away. The places looks tiny, corridor-like and they feels alike. The theme itself is not that bad, but is not a rule that each of the sections need to look almost the same.Overall, I can recommend this title only to those who are really die-hard fans of the rpg genre and have the patience for this.MY OPINION: 6.5/10 (AVERAGE)Graphics: 7/10World Design: 7/10Gameplay: 6/10Sound: 7/10Replay Value: 6/10

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Where to start this review of 'Mars: War Logs'. I understand that I have only play just under 20minets. But just hear me out.This game was Relese in 2013. Expectations where high. But i do under stand the RPGs are really big games to buildAs a pc gamer, I was expecting this game to be good from that trailer that Spiders Studios release. But this is where it has taken as complete U-Turn. Play with as mouse and keybourd like that majoraty of PC plays. We began this game with as avrage cut scene to get some back story, befoer handed the controls. After going through 5mins of base story that explains who this character taht you will be getting the story through. We meet the character that you play. Starting out where i can now move it began to fall apart. I can see veay clearly that this game was 100% desihned for a controler not keybourd and mouse. normal that is not a really big problem for me but this game just felt really clunky through all the animation blending and hot the character respoind to the commands.Combat was very basic only need about 3 keys to fight Strick, Block and Block Breaking. A very simple fighting game style, but I felt it need something more something to stand alone from other RPG's. But saddly i had to stop after finishing of the first guy.After completeing just the little bit I was done.Texture where very low even on high I can see all the detail in the 512X512 maps. I was hopeing that they would have pushed it a little more.Animations Felt like it was on the second pass of the Animation stage and need more time spent on. Considering there are lot of closes ups on faces and the lip sinking was off.Controls really clunky, if going to play it controler you may get better game play.Over all if your RPG fan maybe try it if you have finished all other games from AAA companys. If your looking to buy it there are a lot better RPGs out there than this one. That is why i would NOT Recommend this on PC.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
 Mars: War Logs In the masterfully crafted "Mars: War Logs" (which is in fact a war-diary), we are transported to a martian "anti reality", where societal norms regarding sexual orientation are questioned and examined in series of autisticly voice-acted scenes populated with uncanny-valley robo-people. "The War", (referenced in the title), is actually culture-war being fought not only on the Martian landscape, but within ourselves.  Story 10/10   Gameplay 10/10   Graphics 9/10   Overall Like a million/10 Story 10/10: In this game, you play  a man metaphorically questioning his own sexuality whilst constantly being thrust into combat scenarios  where the only way to survive is to forcefully bludgeon others with handcrafted electro-phalluses.  Our  protagonist hails from a martian colony called "Aurora";  a symbol of cis-genedered norms. Aurora issues "virtue-names" to each inhabitant  like "temprance", "honesty", "morality", "steely-dan" and "jazz-organ" as if to imply a life of freedomless societal predestination. Our doucheburn-wearing antihero held rank in "The Source". "The Source" is a guild of "technomancers", a group of pick-up artists who have dedicated a lifetime of hot-gluing wires and glowsticks to their bodies in a misguided attempt at peacocking. Rejecting this worldview, he is cast down into a dirty man-prison festering with debauchery. It is in this gay-underworld that our protagonist takes his first steps in breaking away from breeder-culture and changes from his assigned name "Temperance" to "Roy", the name of a gay space-cowboy.All is well in the Brokeback Mars Mountain-Prison until one day a strapping young bronco named "Innocence" appears one day, in the shower room. After defending him from an attempted♥♥♥♥♥♥(yes that's what happens), "Innocence" thanks you and becomes your new buckaroo-boyfriend. Innocence then keeps a scrapbook, where he draws fanart about the main character, and talks about his feelings. (This is where the game gets its name, by the way.)After bonding with Innocence by digging through trash bins, rubble heaps and rotten mushroom patches for a few hours, Roy and his young buck decide to "break out of the closet" by stealing a train, and returning to Aurora. Ideally, this is where where they will organize a "resistance" that will pridefully march in the streets and overturn societal norms.Gameplay 10/10:The gameplay consists primarily of combat and dialogue. The dialog feels largely forced, much like the expectation our protagonist feels to conform to society. Your character is almost entirely sent on errands, in an effort to highlight the meaninglessness of life without freedom. You are both figuratively and literally wasting away in a prison! This nihilist gesture is surely to underscore the overarching theme of resisting cultural assimilation and cisexual assumptions.In a bold move, the extended metaphor of sexual discovery is manifest in akward camera angles during combat. The audience is constantly asking questions like "what am I really trying to see?" and "who am I, in all of this?". The camera encourages you to explore new ways of seeing reality.  The enemies you fight during combat consist of your sexual rivals in the prison, cave dwelling testicle-mutants and pick up artists wearing rave-gloves. Despite the fact humans have clearly terraformed Mars, you are restricted to fighting with nailguns and crude batons. You must therefore "assert dominance" over your foes by forcefully employing these erotically-shaped instruments in a symbolic display of fertility and potency.


Красавельчик. 
A Screenshot of Mars: War Logs
By: BigDen




This half-man half-testicle is a visceral manifestation of your latent sexual urges.However, with the slow response speed and erratic camera movements, much like the theme of the game, the real enemy is yourself, thus highlighting the thematic motifs present in the story.Graphics 9/10:In another bold artistic gesture, the developers decided to maek every mesh appear as robotic and lifeless as possible during the dialogue. This is clearly an allusion to a dystopian reality, where "every cog has its place" and personal freedom is stifled. Every landscape is a exercise in monotony and every texture is visual litter.  Everything, (even your clothing), is covered with the same blurry rust, soot and grunge; a clear attempt to give Mars a literal and figurative sense of 'uncanny valley', a fitting location for our symbolic tale. I feel like this Idea could have been explored more throughly, hence the 9.Overall integer-overflow/10:If you're the right kind of player, itching for a game to make you question yourself, social norms, and why you spend money on Mars: War Logs, this is a game that will raise the right questions. I have never seen a game so experimentally break the 4th wall by intentionally crippling core gaming features in service to a noble theme. Bravo!Sadly however; I cannot recommend this game. I don't think most people are ready for this. Mars logs is simply ahead of its time.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Your first impression will be that this game was made on an extremely tight budget.  The voice acting was pretty bad, the animations were anything but smooth, and while the graphics aren't bad, they're not good either. All that being said, this is a satisfying game as long as you're not expecting a mind-blowing experience.  You can genuinely feel for some of the characters and the story is very interesting, even though its rather simple. It is apparrent that the developers put all of what they had into this game, it just wasn't enough to make it great. Also as a side note, the combat system is rather frusterating at times but it doea have a satisfying punch behind it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												First: it's a fun game. It's worth $5 and 15 hours, but don't buy it unless it's on sale.This is a case of a game not having the resources required to meet its vision.  The core idea behind the game is good, if not entirely gripping:  you take the role of a typical hero on Mars, deciding the fate of its people and factions.  The area design is decent: combats are interesting and there's a certain limited amount of exploring to do.  The environments and character models are visually appealing, but there are far too few of them. The entire game, apart from one area at the end, uses almost all the same object models (doors, walls, boxes, piles of junk, etc).The skill design is decent: there are actual choices to be made that affect how your character approaches combat.  There are a few choices to be made, story-wise, but it never feels like they really have an impact.If you're looking for another Mass Effect, this isn't it, although it tries to be.  If you're looking for 15-20 hours of solid gameplay, go for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Many people who review this indie games would come up with a conclusion of "This game is great for an indie developer".While that's very true, I believe that this isn't just great for an indie game - but instead, this game is AMAIZING! Full stop."Why?" you might ask.Well...I like this think this game captures enough of how a lot games used to be: focusing just the right amount of time on each part of the game; story, world, environment (visuals), characters and gameplay. Can't say that about many games that get released these days.The game introduces you to the concept quickly, yet efficiently. There's just enough said so that not too much is told and it makes you want to go explore and learn about the world around you, and characters.The combat isn't perfect, I have to admit. There are a couple of faults and bugs here and there. But it's on of those combat models which is challanging - and requires quite a few tries until you get used to it. Especially when you're trying to complete the game on hardcore difficulty...The best part of the game is the story. There is no "right or wrong" or "good or bad". It's a story, with complications and twists round every corner. I won't spoil too much...It provides a good 10-15 hours depending on how many side missions you take on and how much time you invest in conversations. Usually, I would say it's too short - but it didn't cost a lot (I got it when released - not on a sale).So yeh. Get this game - it is simply amaizing! I'd really recommend it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Its a pretty good game, not disimilar to start wars knights of the old repbulic and mass effect.It has a nice resource system, scavenging parts, and upgrading weapons and armour. Equally it has a choice driven story with actions changing the game progression. The combat is pretty fun, although once you have the mechanics down it feels the same every time. Theres also a leveling system although its not as intuitive as it could easily have been, and the explanations of how it works are fairely poor.The game suffers from some very basic visuals, and poor oversight in its development, such as when I spared some people and it stated id killed them in the diary.Equally, some points of the plot are very poorly written, to the extent that on the spot you could come up with more feasible dialogue.During cutscenes or dialogue exchanges you can also notice the seams where bits are played based on your choices, which kind of kills the atmosphere. And the dialogue is very limited, with very few available exchanges or choices.Perhaps the most damning fact is the game is brutally short. For the time iv played it i would expect to be no more than a quarter of the way through it. It feels like it could have been so good, and at times you actually become interested in whats going on, but the development is so shallow, and as soon as you find something interesting the game rushes onto something else.Had I paid full price, this would be a down vote and id be pretty angry. But given I got it cheap on sale, and that it is a pretty small publisher im pretty happy with it.If you can get it cheap, go for it. Otherwise id avoid it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												When a RPG or action-RPG is smaller, simpler and humbler than "monsters" as Morrowind or Mass Effect it doesn't mean that it's a bad game; it depends of their potential and the better or worse development of its own scope and capabilities. The stealth subject is, by far, the worst implemented part of the game. You cannot exploit all of its hidden potential despite you upgrade al your stealh related skills (for not mentioning that you're the one alerting a gang of idle/patrolling foes, but your partners are blessed with "feather feet" and won't alert them even when they run in front of them -that makes a bad and very ugly impression-). But the rest of the game features goes from the good implemented to the very well implemented. All the RPG part in this game is very simple, but you won't find any lack of fun for it. Visuals in this game are always good and, sometimes, they're stunning. Its atmosphere is well implemented (in the line of Mad Max, Chronichles of Riddick or Borderlands).Combats are tremendous, almost a matter of button twitching but, again, fun and addictive (the fact of almost stopping the time -but not completely- for determining an action or give an order to your partner gives a chance for you to not think only about twitching).Sounds and ambient music make its role, and voice are pretty well (at least the voices in english, I can't understand some comments regarding to the awful voice acting but to refering to other languages, or it's me that I ain't so demanding on this term -but I don't think so-). :PThrowing sand to the eyes of human enemies not protected with Riddick-style-sunglasses is a feature I'd never seen before in a game, and useful a lot.History is fragmented, there's not a clearly central plot involved as their tittle ("War Logs") suggests, and mainly focused in the friendship between the two protagonists and their fight for survival.In resume, a well planned game (and well executed almost all the time) that is absolutely worthing of a try. Just don't expect a complex and big "monster" as the above mentioned (which they're not games, they're UNIVERSES) with a rich amount of player statistics.

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Mars: War Logs piqued my interest right from the start. This indie role-playing game boasts a unique setting and world to explore. The game has plenty of action, but also provides customization through skill trees and crafting.Both of those aspects are nice, but don't feel like fully fleshed-out concepts. I find myself wishing the game was longer, not only because it's a bit on the short side, but because I want to learn more about the fascinating places and characters introduced in the story. This game feels like a great introduction to this universe and I hope to see more.  It could use a bit more polish and variety, but the game remains fun depsite the rough edges and is certainly worth playing.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Why do I like this game? Probably just because I love games that allow you to be the one to make the main character's moral decisions and influence the game's final ending. I beat the game pretty quickly despite the fact that I had to replay multiple parts, and I didn't love the combat, though it was still fun. I found the few characters that were actually developed to some degree to be quite interesting, and the ability to influence the final outcome, and who lives and dies is just something I always enjoy in an rpg.What's wrong with it? For one dialog is confusing, it's not like in mass effect which gives you, good bad and neutral, in fact it makes little distinction obvious, at times I felt like there was no difference in the choices I was given, and what irrirated me the most was when I clicked an option, but what the character said seemed to be nothing like what the option said. Also as I said before, combat was relatively fun and challenging but nothing to write home about.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												So just finished this game (only 18 hours start to finish so short game) and its a bag of mixed feelings on it.The Good:The idea, premise, and even setting of game is spectacular and draws you in. You want to like this gameThe story is good but also bad (thats explained in the bed section)The Bad:The combat in this game sucks huge. The timing is off and the UI is clunky. Many time syou will enter combat to find out you have no companion because he/she is stuck in the entrace still.-As said above, story is mixed bag of good and bad. Why its that is it makes these huge leaps forward in time with no warning or exlaination. One character literally went from hating me and wanting to kill me, to questioning her faith, to being in love with me, IN ONE CONVERSATION. So you end up doing adouble take and wondering what the hell just happened.-Thats the problem, the writers knew where they wanted to take the story, and its a good story, but instead of flowing from start to finish its jump jump jump and often in those juumps your left wondering how such a huge change happened.-Maps/zones are quit small in size and because of that you find yourself loading into combat befor eyour compaion joins inOver all I would give this game a 9/10 on potential but a 5/10 on delivering and meeting potentialThe concept is sound and appealingThey just needed better writers and more back story and lore to discover

												Why do I like this game? Probably just because I love games that allow you to be the one to make the main character's moral decisions and influence the game's final ending. I beat the game pretty quickly despite the fact that I had to replay multiple parts, and I didn't love the combat, though it was still fun. I found the few characters that were actually developed to some degree to be quite interesting, and the ability to influence the final outcome, and who lives and dies is just something I always enjoy in an rpg.What's wrong with it? For one dialog is confusing, it's not like in mass effect which gives you, good bad and neutral, in fact it makes little distinction obvious, at times I felt like there was no difference in the choices I was given, and what irrirated me the most was when I clicked an option, but what the character said seemed to be nothing like what the option said. Also as I said before, combat was relatively fun and challenging but nothing to write home about.

												A sudden game to show up on Steam, and their trailer really sold me into buying the game.Overall the game can be completed over 2 days, but less if you decide to skip side mission.The odd story is actually that another person is telling the beginning, but this will ultimately change depending on what side you chose later in the game.There is a good difficulty in the game, and you need to be choseful into combat depending on what "spec" you go with. Renegade being the rogue is very useful compared to many other games. Later on you unlock the Technomancer ability, which is sort of a caster style with lightning. It's pretty steam punk'ish.In term of quality, then I'd compare this game with Of Orcs and Men. The graphics, sound etc. are fluid and run extremely well. When starting Mars: War Logs you more or less instantly pop into the menu. The only difference is that this game is somewhat more short, yet quite entertaining.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												When a RPG or action-RPG is smaller, simpler and humbler than "monsters" as Morrowind or Mass Effect it doesn't mean that it's a bad game; it depends of their potential and the better or worse development of its own scope and capabilities. The stealth subject is, by far, the worst implemented part of the game. You cannot exploit all of its hidden potential despite you upgrade al your stealh related skills (for not mentioning that you're the one alerting a gang of idle/patrolling foes, but your partners are blessed with "feather feet" and won't alert them even when they run in front of them -that makes a bad and very ugly impression-). But the rest of the game features goes from the good implemented to the very well implemented. All the RPG part in this game is very simple, but you won't find any lack of fun for it. Visuals in this game are always good and, sometimes, they're stunning. Its atmosphere is well implemented (in the line of Mad Max, Chronichles of Riddick or Borderlands).Combats are tremendous, almost a matter of button twitching but, again, fun and addictive (the fact of almost stopping the time -but not completely- for determining an action or give an order to your partner gives a chance for you to not think only about twitching).Sounds and ambient music make its role, and voice are pretty well (at least the voices in english, I can't understand some comments regarding to the awful voice acting but to refering to other languages, or it's me that I ain't so demanding on this term -but I don't think so-). :PThrowing sand to the eyes of human enemies not protected with Riddick-style-sunglasses is a feature I'd never seen before in a game, and useful a lot.History is fragmented, there's not a clearly central plot involved as their tittle ("War Logs") suggests, and mainly focused in the friendship between the two protagonists and their fight for survival.In resume, a well planned game (and well executed almost all the time) that is absolutely worthing of a try. Just don't expect a complex and big "monster" as the above mentioned (which they're not games, they're UNIVERSES) with a rich amount of player statistics.
