content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Mars: War Logs piqued my interest right from the start. This indie role-playing game boasts a unique setting and world to explore. The game has plenty of action, but also provides customization through skill trees and crafting.Both of those aspects are nice, but don't feel like fully fleshed-out concepts. I find myself wishing the game was longer, not only because it's a bit on the short side, but because I want to learn more about the fascinating places and characters introduced in the story. This game feels like a great introduction to this universe and I hope to see more.  It could use a bit more polish and variety, but the game remains fun depsite the rough edges and is certainly worth playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												First: it's a fun game. It's worth $5 and 15 hours, but don't buy it unless it's on sale.This is a case of a game not having the resources required to meet its vision.  The core idea behind the game is good, if not entirely gripping:  you take the role of a typical hero on Mars, deciding the fate of its people and factions.  The area design is decent: combats are interesting and there's a certain limited amount of exploring to do.  The environments and character models are visually appealing, but there are far too few of them. The entire game, apart from one area at the end, uses almost all the same object models (doors, walls, boxes, piles of junk, etc).The skill design is decent: there are actual choices to be made that affect how your character approaches combat.  There are a few choices to be made, story-wise, but it never feels like they really have an impact.If you're looking for another Mass Effect, this isn't it, although it tries to be.  If you're looking for 15-20 hours of solid gameplay, go for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Its a pretty good game, not disimilar to start wars knights of the old repbulic and mass effect.It has a nice resource system, scavenging parts, and upgrading weapons and armour. Equally it has a choice driven story with actions changing the game progression. The combat is pretty fun, although once you have the mechanics down it feels the same every time. Theres also a leveling system although its not as intuitive as it could easily have been, and the explanations of how it works are fairely poor.The game suffers from some very basic visuals, and poor oversight in its development, such as when I spared some people and it stated id killed them in the diary.Equally, some points of the plot are very poorly written, to the extent that on the spot you could come up with more feasible dialogue.During cutscenes or dialogue exchanges you can also notice the seams where bits are played based on your choices, which kind of kills the atmosphere. And the dialogue is very limited, with very few available exchanges or choices.Perhaps the most damning fact is the game is brutally short. For the time iv played it i would expect to be no more than a quarter of the way through it. It feels like it could have been so good, and at times you actually become interested in whats going on, but the development is so shallow, and as soon as you find something interesting the game rushes onto something else.Had I paid full price, this would be a down vote and id be pretty angry. But given I got it cheap on sale, and that it is a pretty small publisher im pretty happy with it.If you can get it cheap, go for it. Otherwise id avoid it.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Many people who review this indie games would come up with a conclusion of "This game is great for an indie developer".While that's very true, I believe that this isn't just great for an indie game - but instead, this game is AMAIZING! Full stop."Why?" you might ask.Well...I like this think this game captures enough of how a lot games used to be: focusing just the right amount of time on each part of the game; story, world, environment (visuals), characters and gameplay. Can't say that about many games that get released these days.The game introduces you to the concept quickly, yet efficiently. There's just enough said so that not too much is told and it makes you want to go explore and learn about the world around you, and characters.The combat isn't perfect, I have to admit. There are a couple of faults and bugs here and there. But it's on of those combat models which is challanging - and requires quite a few tries until you get used to it. Especially when you're trying to complete the game on hardcore difficulty...The best part of the game is the story. There is no "right or wrong" or "good or bad". It's a story, with complications and twists round every corner. I won't spoil too much...It provides a good 10-15 hours depending on how many side missions you take on and how much time you invest in conversations. Usually, I would say it's too short - but it didn't cost a lot (I got it when released - not on a sale).So yeh. Get this game - it is simply amaizing! I'd really recommend it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												This is low key the most under rated RPG ever. Yes the budget may have been like 2 cents and it may have been way too ambitious of a project but the end result is still very much worth checking out. If you are like me and don't really care about all the fluff Bioware has been adding to their games recently, but still like their stories and characters, this game is for you.  Important note: They got a lot of new voice actors and re did a lot of the bad voice overs. So the annoying voices in the trailers are not actually in the game (although LOL@ Innocence randomly getting a British accent)Pros+Story very enjoyable. Not a huge grand adventure but still I found it interesting, and found most characters to actually be pretty good. +The setting is amazing and I hope at some point it can be revisited. +Visually very beautiful. (Design wise, graphics themselves are ok if you care about that lol)+The combat actually has a lot of fun elements to it, and I also enjoyed the character custimization. It doesn't play like most other WRPGs, but I didn't really mind although I know some do.+Roy is a preset character whose pretty defined but you still have a lot of flexibility with how he acts in conversations. Compare to auto dialogue mess Shepard from ME3? I'll take Roy/Temperance any day. +So many good ideas LOL normally I would not suggest this but a bigger company needs to buy Spiders and give them some $$$ and direction. Once they have those 2 things they could honestly be the new Bioware. Cons-The game is small scale. There won't be a billion items to collect or places to explore. A lot of simplified elements but honestly who actually cares? I don't get much out of endlessly exploring desolate areas (Thanks Skyrim for bringing this awful trend back) -Combat can be wonky and annoying at times -Level design is... not the best. A lot of backtracking around the Jail/City/Other city depending on what act you are inThe game is pretty short which could be a pro or a con. Also I still don't know if I find the virtue names cliche or really interesting. Maybe its best there probably won't be a sequal, I can't imagine there are that many virtues left for them to pick from for new characters lolEDIT: I LIED A SEQUEL IS COMING LMAO. MY BODY IS READY !!tl;dr this game is good if you are willing to overlook some things

Posted: July 28, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. The story sounded pretty cool. I think this could have made a great graphic novel. As a game, well this particular iteration is a bit lacking. Combat is repetitive and gets quite boring. I found myself running around talking to everyone to learn more about the game world and story but getting bored with the grind of combat. After awhile I just didn't enjoy playing anymore so despite the developing story I had to quit before finishing the game. Graphics were not bad but again nothing spectacular. I suppose my most constructive critique is that I feels like the writer has an awesome story to tell, I could see the seeds there, but there was some sort of failure in translation. The ideas start off so great in their mind but when it is transcribed to a game it feels like parts, and probably important ones, were left out due to time constraints and technical limitations. Hopefulthis gives the devs the encouragement to keep at it and realize their vision and maybe branch out and put together a graphic novel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												PROS+ Decent story with surprising choice-driven consequences,+ the story was memorable,+ Music is good,+ Excellent skill tree,+ Nice weapon and armor update system, + Combat system is very much like Batman Arkham Asylum and Mad Max,+ Value priced @ $15; even better if on sale,+ there's a sequel out now if you enjoyed this adventure and wanted to continue it,CONS- The ending felt a little rushed,- The Epilogue could've been better,- Voice acting is occasionally bad,- Too many loading screens- As you can see from my playtime, it is short, likely between 7 - 15 hoursFINAL THOUGHTS: I like this game. It reminded me of the low expectations I had when I played Gothic 1 and Witcher 1. I ended up buying The Technomancer. only because I liked how the Mars' story felt at the end. Overall it is a good RPG with many of the RPG elements you come to expect including unexpected choice consequences. Plus the combat system and skill tree makes the game fun. Also, there's are several points where you can replay to make a different choice to see a different outcome.FINAL VERDICT: 7/10

												I liked it. The game has its flaws sure but honestly the game has a neat feel to it. More than one way to approach most situations in this game. Nearly every quest has multiple options on how to handle things. The skill trees are pretty fun especially technomancer. I would go as far to say that it sorta reminds me of kotor with the way its designed. Its not as good as kotor so dont buy this thinking its the best thing ever but it reminds me of a time in gaming where less is more. The armor and Weapon customization is cool. The story and lore is fairly original (Think boarderlands meets fallout) and you need to remember that the developers here arent Activision or Ubisoft. Even the staff roll at the end was pretty short so all that considered they did a great job with what they had to work with. All in all id say that if you enjoy the occasional rpg thats not typical then I say its more than worth a try.Definitley recomend it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Mars:  War Logs really deserves a neutral rating, and I once again find myself regretting that Steam doesn’t offer the option to rate a game that way.  It takes about 10 hours to finish the game (including all the side quests).  The big complaint everyone seems to have is that the combat system sucks.  The controls do take some getting used to (I elected to play without a controller based on complaints about shoddy controller support), but you start to get a feel for it after a few battles.  The combat system demands that you constantly kite around enemies by rolling to get in solid blows and avoid taking damage.  Unfortunately, some battle take place in cramped spaces that make battles a pain.  It is also unfortunate that all of your Technomancer powers have a slight delay before they are used, which leaves you open to having the move cancelled.  The camera sometimes glitches during battles, and the game isn’t shy about sending huge numbers of enemies at you.  It’s fine if you are playing on easy, but I think harder difficulties would prove to be unpleasant.  You should be able to tell after a few battles if it’s going to be a deal-breaker or not for you, and that is well within the refund window.Let’s talk about the rest of the game.  Spiders is a small studio, and the fact that Mars:  War Logs is a budget title does show.  You’ll see the same character models over and over again and the environments are very stale.  Some of the dialog is poorly written, but overall, I think both the setting and the story are enjoyable.  The game does manage to tell a cohesive story in 10 hours or so, but I couldn’t help feeling like something was missing while I was playing the game.  The main character is awesome, but the morality system is underdeveloped:  nobody cares how evil you are most of the time, and being good seems to come with comparatively fewer rewards.  The three romance choices were very shallow (almost an afterthought, really).  I can’t stress enough how the stale environments are, though the background art is generally good.Overall, I liked the game, but it won’t be for everyone.  I was actually ready for the game to be done when it ended despite the short length, and I don’t see it being an RPG I’ll play through again.  If you are interested in the game, pick it up on sale.  If you aren’t enjoying the game by about an hour in, or if the combat seems like an aberration to you, go ahead and refund the game.  The Technomancer powers you get at the end of the first chapter don’t significantly change the combat, and I felt the first chapter of the game was actually the strongest.

Some of the dialog is poorly written, but overall, I think both the setting and the story are enjoyable.  The game does manage to tell a cohesive story in 10 hours or so, but I couldn’t help feeling like something was missing while I was playing the game.  The main character is awesome, but the morality system is underdeveloped:  nobody cares how evil you are most of the time, and being good seems to come with comparatively fewer rewards.  The three romance choices were very shallow (almost an afterthought, really).  I can’t stress enough how the stale environments are, though the background art is generally good.Overall, I liked the game, but it won’t be for everyone.  I was actually ready for the game to be done when it ended despite the short length, and I don’t see it being an RPG I’ll play through again.  If you are interested in the game, pick it up on sale.  If you aren’t enjoying the game by about an hour in, or if the combat seems like an aberration to you, go ahead and refund the game.  The Technomancer powers you get at the end of the first chapter don’t significantly change the combat, and I felt the first chapter of the game was actually the strongest.

												PROS+ Decent story with surprising choice-driven consequences,+ the story was memorable,+ Music is good,+ Excellent skill tree,+ Nice weapon and armor update system, + Combat system is very much like Batman Arkham Asylum and Mad Max,+ Value priced @ $15; even better if on sale,+ there's a sequel out now if you enjoyed this adventure and wanted to continue it,CONS- The ending felt a little rushed,- The Epilogue could've been better,- Voice acting is occasionally bad,- Too many loading screens- As you can see from my playtime, it is short, likely between 7 - 15 hoursFINAL THOUGHTS: I like this game. It reminded me of the low expectations I had when I played Gothic 1 and Witcher 1. I ended up buying The Technomancer. only because I liked how the Mars' story felt at the end. Overall it is a good RPG with many of the RPG elements you come to expect including unexpected choice consequences. Plus the combat system and skill tree makes the game fun. Also, there's are several points where you can replay to make a different choice to see a different outcome.FINAL VERDICT: 7/10

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												At 12 hours of play time and a sale price, I found this game worth it. Twelve hours of gameplay was nice, because the clunkiness of the game overall might have outworn its welcome past that. The clunkiness includes voice acting, set design, and combat. Sadly, this short play time also means that the characterization of characters was pretty rushed, especially the companion Mary. So, the game could have been longer with better story and characterization or better gameplay, and I'd likely recommend it at full price if that were the case.What I did like was the setting and overall story, which means I'm looking forward to the sort of sequel in the works, Technomancer.  I did have fun with the gameplay more when I got into the full swing of the Techromancer powers. I liked the ability to craft armor, weapons, health packs, explosives, however this could have all been fleshed out more.I also particularly liked the titular premise, the game being the War Logs of the aptly named character Innocence. I think that shows some storytelling promise from Spiders.If they learned from this game, I'm excited to see the results of their sort of sequel, Technomancer. If they got about the same results with better graphics, I'll likely wait until that drops below $10 too.

												Ok, I'll give a recommend, but just barely and it isn't because the graphics are washed out and lifeless. It's because the story was uninspiring. I lost interest in it about 3/4 of the way through. But there are some redeeming factors in the game:1. Boss battles are challenging2. The loot is finite which makes crafting ever so important3. And finally the combat is very atypical. There are no real guns/weapons in the game. You can fashion a nailgun into a weapon but thats the only firearm in the game. However, you can make grenades and mines. You get different types of melee weapons that can be modified to enhance combat and your stats. Your armor is modified in the same way. But the most important combat is done using technomancy which is basically the ability to wield electricity and shockwaves.The skilltree is huge and I was only able to fill 2/4 of the branches so choose wisely on your path.The side quests pay very well in experience, but you'll find yourself asking why you accepted this mission (oh right, the XP).The ending was very forgetable as were most of the characters. Play it for the combat not the story.5/10

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Mars:  War Logs really deserves a neutral rating, and I once again find myself regretting that Steam doesn’t offer the option to rate a game that way.  It takes about 10 hours to finish the game (including all the side quests).  The big complaint everyone seems to have is that the combat system sucks.  The controls do take some getting used to (I elected to play without a controller based on complaints about shoddy controller support), but you start to get a feel for it after a few battles.  The combat system demands that you constantly kite around enemies by rolling to get in solid blows and avoid taking damage.  Unfortunately, some battle take place in cramped spaces that make battles a pain.  It is also unfortunate that all of your Technomancer powers have a slight delay before they are used, which leaves you open to having the move cancelled.  The camera sometimes glitches during battles, and the game isn’t shy about sending huge numbers of enemies at you.  It’s fine if you are playing on easy, but I think harder difficulties would prove to be unpleasant.  You should be able to tell after a few battles if it’s going to be a deal-breaker or not for you, and that is well within the refund window.Let’s talk about the rest of the game.  Spiders is a small studio, and the fact that Mars:  War Logs is a budget title does show.  You’ll see the same character models over and over again and the environments are very stale.  Some of the dialog is poorly written, but overall, I think both the setting and the story are enjoyable.  The game does manage to tell a cohesive story in 10 hours or so, but I couldn’t help feeling like something was missing while I was playing the game.  The main character is awesome, but the morality system is underdeveloped:  nobody cares how evil you are most of the time, and being good seems to come with comparatively fewer rewards.  The three romance choices were very shallow (almost an afterthought, really).  I can’t stress enough how the stale environments are, though the background art is generally good.Overall, I liked the game, but it won’t be for everyone.  I was actually ready for the game to be done when it ended despite the short length, and I don’t see it being an RPG I’ll play through again.  If you are interested in the game, pick it up on sale.  If you aren’t enjoying the game by about an hour in, or if the combat seems like an aberration to you, go ahead and refund the game.  The Technomancer powers you get at the end of the first chapter don’t significantly change the combat, and I felt the first chapter of the game was actually the strongest.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												--Updated--Mars War Logs is a third person RPG with a not so bad story settled in an intresting environment, actually the background had a lot of potential, enought for a prequel/sequel/whatever without the risk o being repetitive.Because of the potential of this environment I expected a little bit more details in the story and side characters development, more than often the characters move in a world that they undestand pefectly (well, it's actually their world, you know) and the player is left wondering about how the plot twist and turn, not knowing much of the background details that may help to get a better grasp of the story and it's meaning.Of course is not like you have no idea of what are you doing, mostly you have to fight for your skin, like in 90% of games out there, and the story is pretty straightforward, maybe just a little bit too straightforward. (mind peolpe, I'm the kind of person that read every single page of a diary, piece of codex, random book, signs and talk to everyone, even if my character is on fire and the NPC is an anvil, so try to take the critique about the story by the point of viev of a details lover)Switching to a more technical side, MWL is a normal RPG, you gain experience by kicking butts, level up and then build you character choosing freely among three branches of specialization.There is also a nice upgrading and crafting system for armor and weapons.The gameplay is actually good when you learn not to freak out because of the game controls, it is similar to what I experienced with The Witcher, when you learn when you are suppose to hit, it goes all nice and smooth.In the end I really liked this game, even if some potential on story, lenght and character development was wasted, it offer a nice min10-max15 hours of gaming and some intresting story and characters.I actually won't mind if Spiders would pop out a more detailed and longer sequel, the lore they have built is worth further depening.-Please don't mind my "monkey on acid" english-

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												This is low key the most under rated RPG ever. Yes the budget may have been like 2 cents and it may have been way too ambitious of a project but the end result is still very much worth checking out. If you are like me and don't really care about all the fluff Bioware has been adding to their games recently, but still like their stories and characters, this game is for you.  Important note: They got a lot of new voice actors and re did a lot of the bad voice overs. So the annoying voices in the trailers are not actually in the game (although LOL@ Innocence randomly getting a British accent)Pros+Story very enjoyable. Not a huge grand adventure but still I found it interesting, and found most characters to actually be pretty good. +The setting is amazing and I hope at some point it can be revisited. +Visually very beautiful. (Design wise, graphics themselves are ok if you care about that lol)+The combat actually has a lot of fun elements to it, and I also enjoyed the character custimization. It doesn't play like most other WRPGs, but I didn't really mind although I know some do.+Roy is a preset character whose pretty defined but you still have a lot of flexibility with how he acts in conversations. Compare to auto dialogue mess Shepard from ME3? I'll take Roy/Temperance any day. +So many good ideas LOL normally I would not suggest this but a bigger company needs to buy Spiders and give them some $$$ and direction. Once they have those 2 things they could honestly be the new Bioware. Cons-The game is small scale. There won't be a billion items to collect or places to explore. A lot of simplified elements but honestly who actually cares? I don't get much out of endlessly exploring desolate areas (Thanks Skyrim for bringing this awful trend back) -Combat can be wonky and annoying at times -Level design is... not the best. A lot of backtracking around the Jail/City/Other city depending on what act you are inThe game is pretty short which could be a pro or a con. Also I still don't know if I find the virtue names cliche or really interesting. Maybe its best there probably won't be a sequal, I can't imagine there are that many virtues left for them to pick from for new characters lolEDIT: I LIED A SEQUEL IS COMING LMAO. MY BODY IS READY !!tl;dr this game is good if you are willing to overlook some things

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Okay, so let's get this out of the way: This is the B movie of RPGs, at best. The dialog is stilted, the character animations are stiff, the character development is shallow at best. There are stale tropes everywhere, both of the game sort (Pointless crafting system that has you spend a third of your time rummaging through crates and piles of trash? Camera that spins around in combat? Binary branching plotlines? All check) and of the narrative sort. The protagonist is incredibly bland, pretty much all the female characters are given stereotypical roles, obesity is used as a visual marker for sexual predation, and the threat of sexual violence hangs heavy over the miserable denizens of Mars (though interestingly, it hangs over men as well as women). There's a seedy bar that you can find by following the street signs helpfully advertising "Seedy bar". It's not a great story, nor a great game.That said, I always try to look for the positives, and Mars: War Logs has some qualities if you're willing to tough out all the issues. Mercifully, it's very stable - I didn't encounter any bugs or obviously broken systems. Beyond that low bar, though, combat is surprisingly streamlined and fluid. It's simple, understandable, and actually fun - and to my shock, most of the enemies you defeat aren't actually killed, but rather just left writhing on the floor (you can choose to kill them for extra cash, but I never needed to). It might actually be one of the most bloodless RPGs I've ever played, and it's done in such a simple, obvious way that it makes me feel a bit gross about all the other RPGs where I play as the good guy but slaughter hundreds or thousands.The art style (minus the animation) is actually pretty good, creating a rusty-feeling world and some strategically-placed sci-fi aesthetics, such as with the Technomancers. The story also has a few genuinely unexpected twists. At least three times I found myself surprised or even shocked that things weren't going the way I had expected them to, and that's rare. I don't know how the developers managed to craft a game that was 90% shallow tropes and 10% really surprising and interesting turns, but they did it.The world itself is also really interesting. Mars often shows up in fiction either as a harsh wilderness to be tamed (in early colonization settings) or a rebellious, oppressed colony struggling against greedy Earth overlords (in late colonization settings). Mars: War Logs does something different entirely - Earth or even spaceflight barely get any mention at all, and instead Mars feels like it's been abandoned, with people fighting over scraps of water and fertile soil. There's also a fantasy-esque vibe to the setting that is really interesting, and it's enough to make me put the sequel (The Technomancer) firmly on my wishlist.So in short: this is, at best, a bargain bin, shoestring budget version of Mass Effect, written by people who mostly uncritically repeat tropes from other media. But it takes place in an interesting world and has hints of intelligent and surprising writing, and the gameplay is entirely welcoming. Give it a shot if you can appreciate or tolerate the videogame equivalent of eyerolling B-movie cheese, and you may just find yourself enjoying it and wanting more.(And better. Please, please let The Technomancer have better writing.)

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												While Mars: War Logs is not a AAA game I still enjoyed it a lot.  Enough so to go back and replay it to see the other ending.  Almost all aspects of the game scream indie meaning things like Voice acting, character animations, character customization/skills, etc., are done failry well, but not quite as polished and deep as you see in other major titles like Mass Effect  In one respect, you could almost consider it a rudimentary version of Mass Effect.  Playing through the game you'll notice these shortcomings or lack of depth in each aspect of the game, but if you can look past theses definitely enjoy the game.To be honost I am a bit of a snob and won't touch games unless they're of AAA caliber.  Mainly because I don't have a lot of time to play games so I want to spend what time I have on worth while games.  By chance I decided to give this game a try and the first couple hours of gameplay were enough to pull me in.  The environment and setting of the game look absolutely amazing.  The devs did a great job of creating a dystopian city on mars.  I found the story quite interesting and kept me intrigued throughout most of the game.  There are some pacing issues towards the middle, but if you stick to the main quest line, you can power through through these slow points fairly quickly.  The other thing this game did well was the combat system.  I thought it was done quite well feeling very smooth and polished.  It never felt awkward or clumsy where my character was slow or didnt attack when I wanted him to.  The one thing I found to be a bit irritating was its very easy to be swarmed by a group of enemies and die.  But to be honest this serves to make it more challenging.All in all regardless of the shortcoming I still very much enjoyed this game.  A solid 7/10TL;DRGreat story and combat system but lacks depth in all other aspects of the game.  They are still done well so if you can look past this shortcoming you'll definitely enjoy this game

												Worth playing twice.Cons: chapter 1 puts most people off, if you want to quit should download a chapter 2 start savepoint.Cons: POV camera angle is CRAP, there is no in game setting, but you can manually edit the setting making the POV perfectPros: I like the story well thought out, I like the fork in the story, hence 2nd playPros: The weapon armor self-upgrades are excellent, could spend hours looking into the best upgrade'Pros: The combat, the combat, once you can zap your enemy then you rule, so many options in combat, keeping up shield defence, kicking, weapon attack, avoid, shoot, trow grenade, all of it needed at times on the hardest playthrough.If you like RPG with great combat & good story its well worth it. -just get past the first chapter &( keep 10+ free skill points to use in begining of chap2) before giving up.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												At the point of writing this I have almost beaten the game and am enjoying it, yes there are some flaws to the game but they can easily be over looked if you are the type of gamer who likes to read into all the lore you collect during the game.I would recommend this game to gamers who enjoy learning the ingame lore and I would wait for it to go on sale if you plan on purchasing it. I would sum this game up as, the game it what you make it out to be.Roleplaying- The game gives you the choices of how to build your character how you want, I play a combat oriented character but you can spec your char out for stealth but most encounters in the game do require you to engage in combat. When it comes to the story it also leaves you with the good or evil approach to most situations. Also there are major story choices you get to make during the game so on the RPG aspect it has the basic points, nothing major like you would see from a Bioware RPG. Also when it comes to equipment the choice is there to custimize it how you want but most of the visually appealing option dont have stats to make them worth it.Combat- Lots of gamers dont like the combat in the game but I find enjoyable, its not flashy like something you would get in the Batman Arkham games. I place combat more like a real life fight, you vs 4 people and they all are try beating up on you at the same time. Unlike most games that have your attackers come at you 1 at a time. Combat requires some thought to it not just going in swinging hoping to beat your enemies to death. I did have to up the difficulty to get the most enjoyment out of the combat.Negatives- The biggest negative to this game is the dialogue in the first area of the game it has poor writting, but once you past it the dialogue gets a lot better. Voice attacking is lack luster and emtionless but I am able to ignore it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Not quite a diamond in the rough. More like a really roughed up diamond. Unimpressive graphics. Mediocre voice acting at best. Interesting story. Lovely combat, that is actually challenging. Too many games these days place combat and gameplay as just a secondary thing tacked onto their "expansive world", and "engaging story". This game may not have the best presentation in the world but it was throughly enjoyable to play, and isn't that what really counts. It has a definite indie vibe running throughout, but in my opinion they managed to put together a decent game. When I read reveiws for this game from publications like IGN, they seem to focus on all the wrong things. They judge it for not being a triple A title, and it seems the "reviewer" didn't even play the game for more than hour. It always seems to me that the Video Game Media just pick a narrative about a game and all the different publications follow suit. Don't listen to that garbage. Steam's ratings is a much truer representation of the quality of this game.

content:
Posted: April 10
												Mars: War logs is a rough diamond with a lot of potential.The first part of the game within the Prison is a bit meh, but afterwards it does get far better. So, I'd recommend sticking with this game a wee bit longer before giving up.It's an unusual RPG game, one that has a lot of potential with an interesting but unusual story set on Mars. Combat is okay but can be challenging, the game is a little bit rough in spots and pacing does need a bit tweaked.However, this game was made by a small studio that clearly put their a lot of effort into this game.If you're am RPG fan, and are looking for something a bit different then give this game a go, even at the current price. But do be aware that it can be a wee bit rough around the edges and the first level is a bit on the 'meh' side.

												20 minutes on record. 10 of which spent trying to figure out how to get a controller to work. Quit out of game and spend 20 minutes online searching for a fix. All I can find are years old threads of people asking the same thing on release. Only problem seems to be to unplug your wireless mouse or keyboard. Of which I have neither. Alright, I'll try it with keyboard and mouse. Notice game is developed by Spiders. Is Spiders trying to corner the market on awful dialogue and voice acting? This game and Bound By Flame both sound like they were written and acted by people who speak English as a third language. Get past the first part of the intro, an NPC is about to be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by a large man appropriately named, "Fatso". PC shows up and stares menacingly at them. They get unnerved (after several lines of cringeworthy dialogue from Fatso) and leave. NPC thanks the PC. First dialogue option of the game, "I couldn't just stand there and do nothing". That's literally what he did. Choose it anyway. Hear PC's voice actor. ALT+F4.
